cons: The company has taken a turn in the wrong direction when it comes to their employees. They took away options for external continuous learning (certifications, paying for SHRM/HRCI, conferences, etc) which hurts the HR team from staying up on their skill-set and thinking outside the box, They took away many opportunities for promotions (they are inconsistently applied and whether unintentional, eludes to favoritism), and they restructured their merit process....if you want to call it a merit process at all. I could go into detail about how ridiculous this strategy is but I will refrain in this review. Just know that a majority, and I mean a majority, of the population does not see any financial fruits of their exceptionally hard work. Their internal equity also needs to be re-evaluated and corrected but they do not want to invest the money in labor costs. Like many companies, the talent market is demanding a higher salary to join H-D. That has left many loyal, long time employees making the same or less that the people coming on now. Further, they are very top heavy with highly compensated leaders and leave those at the lower levels with the stress of producing a tremendous amount of work. And I am not speaking of HR specifically. It is across the board. Bottom line, they may say they care about their employees, but their actions are showing otherwise. It is sad to me for sure. I used to love it there. Now they're just another over-corporatized global company trying to save money in all the wrong ways.

They don't like having their authority or decisions questioned.  That wasn't the case during the Wandell and prior eras but seems to be the case in the Levatich era. "One step forward and two steps back" approach to running a business.

review_title: Not a good place for engineers
pros: Bikes, customers, history, casual dress code
cons:
Leadership, leadership, leadership, leadership, leadership.
Simply, this company has terrible leadership.  Over the last 5 or so years, they managed to fire, lay-off, drive away, humiliate, disappoint, demoralize, antagonize, insult and who knows what else to hundreds of very, very good people who are no longer with the company.  Engineering leadership has been especially poor, from the Senior VP of product development, who is not even an engineer, to the VP, who created an environment that even he could not work in so he took a "voluntary" early retirement, incompetent managers, who should not be entrusted to manage professionals, and I could go on and on...
Bottom line, if you are an engineer, do not expect a career at Harley-Davidson, as the company does not value good engineering, professionalism, and other values that come with it.

review_title: Started working for my dream job and now is a nightmare!
pros:
Working with great people!
Location wise,traffic is minimal to get to work on time
Fitness Center located right at the plant with trainers
cons:
communication is horrible,way too much middle management
Balancing personal life and work isnt flexible,mandatoried over 50+hrs weekly
This company is all about the dollar and upper management is not in touch with employees or customers
Other then the V-rod company makes the same old same old with very little changes
Highly skilled workers have been forced out or better jobs are out there to feel appreciated
A company that once worked very well between salaried and hourly workers has now become salaried versus union!
Benefits and pension have been eliminated or have escalated to very high deductibles

job_title: Senior Project Engineer in Milwaukee, WI
pros: The actual people doing work here are great, the product is awesome, and the customers are fantastic.  It is a toy company after all!
cons: We lack leadership, starting at the corner office, but most directly down into the VP's, Directors, and Chief's level.  LOTS of managers, no leaders.  They do not understand the people side of leading and it shows in everything, starting with a "Yes man" culture.  There is almost no trust from the bottom up.  In the engineering organization, there is MASSIVE change fatigue and the number one complaint is that we are focused more on process than product (and that is putting it nicely).

job_title: Assembly Mechanic in Menomonee Falls, WI
pros: The people care about what they produce and try to strive for quality
cons: No job security will try to keep you as a casual as long as they can.

review_title: Awesome products and fun people, just need to navigate the politics
pros:
Really cool products!
Good group of people to work with
Premium Healthcare
On-site fitness centers, staffed with trainers
Opportunities to interact with customers firsthand at rallies and sponsored events
Lots of new technology and processes
Solid compensation and perks
Good sense of direction for the company with defined mission and stretch goals
cons:
Very much a relationship based company
Non-confrontational, people would rather go to a manager then address a concern or issue firsthand
Lack of accountability with cross-functional teams
Poor HR department, not engaged with nor understand what employee development means
The worst change management and change leadership ever experienced
Organizational structure does not meet the needs of the business
Ambiguity around core business hours, expect to respond to emails and phone calls 7 days a week

pros: The people and the environment are fantastic.  The enthusiasm can not be matched.
cons:
Management seems to be floundering with how to actually manage
The Sr Management do not know what they make so they do not know how to market The Brand.

pros: It's very enjoyable and satisfying if you like motorcycles and dealing with people regularly.  There are many "fun" aspects to working for H-D as in seeing many beautiful bikes regularly and helping people achieve what they envision as their "dream motorcycle.
cons: The monetary compensation for helping people "achieve" their dream bike.  After helping the company reap many thousands of dollars from an individual or group of individuals, you don't receive any compensation nor even a pat on the back.  I could see if you were a standard employee and "just doing your job" tripling your salary in sales to justify keeping you on board, but if you are an over-achiever who does more than that....this isn't the place for you.

review_title: Was great...now it's not so great
pros: Huge brand and a very cool product.  In IS, based on the visionary leadership of the ex-CIO, the business now has capabilities that other companies take for granted, we have personally grown by learning the best technologies (makes us very marketable IT professionals) and  we have stretched our experiences globally.
cons: Sr. Leadership doesn't seem to have the experience to execute, there is too much politics and everybody is out for themselves.  From an IS perspective, when the CIO left we lost our visionary on how to continue to bring Harley into this century (from an IT perspective).  Now it seems that Sr. Leadership thinks we can just keep making the remaining 30 year old systems work in this century.  We just took a giant step backwards in IT.

review_title: Sad state of affairs - all the truly innovative product leaders are gone
job_title: Design Engineer II in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Great Product and History. Great job for those who can have contact with customers. Good opportunity to get a diversified background in product design.
cons: Key leaders are now gone that lead product innovation and design. Since 2005 H-D has disregarded experience and knowledge of product and gone to cheap labor and outsourcing in the effort to bolster its stock (fooling most Wall Street groups). Recent departures of key engineering personnel either by choice or forced out is leaving the company powerless to lead the industry.

pros: I was provided plenty of opportunities for growth and development.  HD rewards employees who work hard and drive results while demonstrating positive behaviors - meaning you can't just steamroll over people to get results.  Good vacation policy including for Milwaukee based salary teams getting a holiday shutdown.  I was compensated fairly and received bonuses.  I felt that leadership listened and valued my opinion.
cons: The company has a tendency to sign up for too much work and don't always know how to stop work that is not necessary.  If you are a high performer there is a feeling or perception that you can not say no to work.

review_title: Hostile environment that is no longer any fun
pros: Cool product, customers are still unbelievably loyal, great co-workers
cons:
Senior Leadership is the worst and Harley has become one of the most political places I've ever seen.  CEO came from the auto world making batteries and is known for breaking people down and outsourcing the world for a buck.  President really only knows purchasing.  Head of engineering also is a purchasing person.  CIO came from purchasing.  Head of HR is a lawyer.  See the pattern?  The prior leadership team understood motorcycling, the brand and were reachable with integrity.  This team will bury you and in a second.  The culture here changed to the worst almost overnight when new leadership took over.

Almost all innovation in product development is gone...basically we are just making the same stuff with different colors and accessories.

review_title: working in support services areas like HR, IT
job_title: Internal Support Service Areas Including Human Resources, IT in Milwaukee, WI
pros: I've supported different areas as a contractor for a while. Over time, I've come to know and appreciate Harley as an incredibly fascinating, powerful and beautiful brand with endless learning opportunities. Let's just say I've made the most of the opportunity in many ways.
cons: As a contractor (and their workforce is increasingly contractors), I've always felt treated like a guest and an outsider who's expendable at any time. No matter how much passion, effort and hard work I put forth (which, in many ways is its own reward since it makes me really "sing for my supper"), I tend to go way above and beyond when I notice other permanent employees a little too comfortable at what seems to be any everyday grind.

job_title: Senior Design Engineer in Wauwatosa, WI
pros: Casual work environment, amazing people, cool product, excellent compensation for the area.  More interesting than the average company.
cons: In product development, the stress is high, the projects never have enough time or resources, and nights/weekends are frequent.   In general engineers and middle managers are reluctant to make decisions because they will frequently be undone by chief-level.  The company seems to hire from the outside rather than promote from within, so it's easier to get in, harder to move up.  It's well known that people will leave, and return to get that promotion.

review_title: Very intelligent skilled workers who are thought of as easily replaceable.
pros: Helpful, smart, and friendly workforce. A lot of tribal knowledge although many of the smart old timers are running for the doors. Clean, organized floor.
cons: The company WAS a great place to work. You used to feel like you were an important part of the family. Now you feel like the scared red headed stepchild of the family. Way too many upper management and bean counters. It's ALL about the stock price now. Employee involvement is almost non existent. If the company could get robotic androids to do the work, they would. Not real interested in suggestions. Just make sure you don't get hurt, or are late for work. They are looking for every reason to try and eliminate higher paid union worker, and replace them with temps, and casual workers at half the price.

review_title: I was very enthusiastic at first but when I reached the 2nd year, things got frustrating.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: There are plenty of amazing people. Working at H-D, next to the bikes, next to Willie G, its awesome (if you are into motorcycles. You feel proud to be part of the legend and its clearly everywhere you go. When you say anywhere you work for H-D it shows in people faces, they expressions changes.
cons: I used to work at a subsidiary, not at the HQ. It was very different. The culture was completely different as everyone came from automotive. They dont really care about the brand and that was extremely sad to see every day.

review_title: Don't believe the hype you may have read in business school case studies
pros: The brand "mystique" and to have it on your resume
cons:
It is both psychologically and emotionally unhealthy environment.  Harley’s systems and processes are incredibly archaic, incompatible with legacy systems and amount to an enormous patchwork of systems that do not communicate with one another. Its inconceivable that a company that is perceived to be so great from the outside is so dysfunctional on the inside.  The true life experience at Harley doesn't remotely come close to the story told in business school case studies.

Departments operate in silos frequently duplicating efforts and spinning their wheels because no one works together on projects - big or small. Each project is riddled with personalities, politicking and backstabbing and at the end of the day, leadership (and I use the term loosely) lacks the capacity to make decisions and are therefore ineffective.

review_title: Any action can be justified if it is "right for the business".
pros: Exciting product and very talented people. Best in class facility and tools in engineering. Pay and benefits are slightly above average but dropping every year. H-D used to be a great place to work.
cons: Engineers treated as a plug & play resource. Assignments are made without regard to interests or career goals. Engineering leadership is old boy network of clones that all think and act the same. Think and act like them or you are gone. Lots of change, which is necessary but no change management or consideration of the impact on people. No work/life balance. It has been a rough three years with at least a year of pain remaining.

job_title: Systems Administrator in Kansas City, MO
pros: Decent facilities, certain type of brand recognition, occasionally good family events around Christmas. The work force in the ranks are the biggest pros, but that mostly goes unnoticed by management.
cons: The culture used to be good but eroded to one of back-biting and intentional misinformation from management to the employees. It was like war was waged on the employees 5+ years ago and it's been all about corporate politics, clock-watching, morale problems and layoffs ever since, pure products of bad leadership.

pros: The people really are great, there is a lot of flexibility and emphasis on freedom.
cons:
Management is horrible.  There is so much concentration on image that it takes over, the window dressing of continuous improvement hides the fact it takes a committee to decide to change the names on the conference rooms. 

Contractors are nearly invisible and treated as second class.  Nepotism is rampant.  if you do not have a strong supporter in management before you interview, keep your expectations low

review_title: Come for a job, not a career.
pros:
The product is made in America, and is an iconic brand.
Many of the people who work at the company are passionate about the product.
Many hard-working people who are good to work with, smart, and will help you if it's needed.
cons:
Organizational changes every 12-24 months.  With each new re-organization, you are back to square one proving yourself to a new boss.
Some bullying goes on between leadership and salary workers to meet tough deadlines.
Workload is very high and you're pushed to meeting tough timing schedules which can sacrifice the quality of the output and be pretty stressful.
Employee development process is very loosely organized and feedback that's collected isn't audited by HR leaving it open to favoritism or targeting.

review_title: Started out as a place to retire from, turned into just a job.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros: Its a Union Job! IF you make a full time job the pay is good. The 4 day-10 hour schedule is ok, its nice to have 3 day weekends but that creates other problems with the long hours.  They still have a pension plan for Full Time Union Employees.
cons: The company has gone to hiring Casuals for all production positions, and the likely hood of getting a full time position is very low since they only use the casuals for Seasonal Surges in production.  The company plans to outsource some work which will lay full time employees off and make casual to full time employment next to impossible since they will have people on recall lists.  Plan to work a lot in the first 6 months of the year with a lot of lay-off days in the 3rd and 4th quarters.

review_title: It's a job, you might like it or not
pros: Paid time off is pretty good. 3 weeks vacation when you start. 4 weeks vacation after five years. There is a winter shutdown each year, which is about 1.5 weeks (so you can be home when kids are on winter break). Discount on motorcycles and merchandise. Casual workplace. Opportunities for training. Pay seems pretty decent for my job category in this area. If you like motorcycles, obviously this is the place to be. Sometimes you can get involved with events.
cons: Some pockets within the company suck (such as mine). Some really great leaders have been removed from the company during the layoffs or have just moved on. Seems that they are looking for leaders that grind people down to get 'results', rather than appreciating inspirational leaders that build people up. They seem to value leaders who run the business like a machine. And while leadership 'talks about' how they care about the workers, there really are no warm fuzzies left anymore. The company had a great 'throwback' culture which was fun and interesting. Felt like family. But now it is just 'another company' with declining culture and evaporating benefits. They do a Q12 survey to see how well people are engaged, but they take the results into a backroom and try to mind-read what the workers want, rather than directly asking employees how to improve conditions. The company talks about everyone being a leader, but that seems to have become license for aggressive people to stomp on everyone else.

review_title: Was a great company... but now senior leadership is lost and hasn't been able to find their way back.
pros:
Good pay.
Benefits are about average.
Most of the people are there because they want to do a good job and make a great product.
cons:
Horrible senior leadership. Blame supervisors for all the problems and make them fix-it, even though the original problems were started by middle to upper management, Managers are completely out of touch with whats going on on the floor.
Promotions are completely based on who you know. (probably no different then any other large company)

review_title: This company has managed to completely devalue its employees, and this is just the beginning
pros:
Great Product and people to work with.
Opportunities to interact with customers (although this seems to be in decline).
Customers appreciate the product and this makes you feel proud to have worked on it.
cons:
Into third year of lay-offs (they call it a "business transformation").
Continued out-sourcing of business - technical and manufacturing.
High level of mistrust in senior leadership created by poor leadership, and continues to get worse.
People were once the key competitive advantage, not so anymore.

pros: Good colleagues - some who are willing to help when management turn their back on you.
cons:
Everything is a con at Harley Heaven in Australia. Management are only interested in looking after themselves, high turnover of staff. The company does not care about staff and only want to achieve impossible targets. They do not pay overtime. Managers are rude and treat their staff as objects. You are expected to do the work on your own and they will not help you and respond always with sarcasm, there have been new staff there that don't last more than 2 days because of the toxic, micro management environment. You can't even breath without having management tell you off or treat you like children if you are even caught LOOKING at your phone. Absolutely disgusted with the company, poor pay - do not recommend anyone to work at any of the Harley Heavens in Sydney, Australia. 

*Please note this is only based on Harley Heaven.

pros: New leadership has made the hard decisions necessary to correct the ship. Senior management has a focus on growth and recognizes the value of employees to that end. Pay and benefits are appropriate, perks are good. Over the past two years, finally throwing out the old-boys network and the "because we've always done it that way" mentality.
cons: Still too much of the old-guard in the ranks who were spoiled in the 90's with excessive pay and benefits for doing almost no work. Those folks complain and complain and complain, constantly believing the company is doing them wrong. Management has made the right moves for the financial health of the company, but a few areas are now under-staffed for the volume of work.

review_title: This is a big company like any other, but the grass still isn't greener elsewhere.
pros: Lots of perks, especially if you like motorcycles.  The pay is very good, and working for this company presents many great opportunities that you would not have working other places.
cons: All large publicly traded companies have to abide by this generic set of rules throughout the organization (think HR department).  The interesting thing about H-D however, is the fact that many of these corporate ideals conflict with the brand's own identity.  One example-  If a beautiful model posed for a harley-davidson calendar, you likely can't hang said calendar at your desk because it's "offensive".  BUT IT'S A HARLEY-DAVIDSON CALENDAR!!

review_title: Harley is a great brand, but the current corporate culture is dominated by fear with very low employee morale.
pros: Harley is a great brand, with great products and great customers.  Customer loyalty is among the highest of any brand.
cons: Harley used to be a great place to work (Fortune top 100).  It is now dominated by a culture of fear.  Successes are not recognized.  Everyone walks around afraid they are going to be fired if they make a mistake.  People hide in their cubes and keeps their heads low.  Not a productive environment.

review_title: Love the brand, not the company
pros: The brilliant minds and friendly people that work there. All the great experiences that I and many others got to do. There was a lot of opportunity to move around.
cons: In the past  couple of years it has become a pretty toxic place to work. Business is business but the continued reorgs and low employee engagement is disheartening. Its a cool product and still proud to have had worked there but just sad that people are exiting on their own and by the powers of business at an alarming rate.

job_title: Causal Machinist in Menomonee Falls, WI
pros: Most people that I worked with were great! They tried to make work fun until supervisors and union stewards would give a stern talking to others that would crack a joke just walking by. Loved walking to my machine and not having to talk to anyone for an entire shift.
cons:
Other individuals took the union business side of things too seriously. I was HATED just because I was a casual and wasn't treated like another human being because I was a causal. I truly think that my experience would have been far better had I been treated like everyone else. Had to pay union dues just to be told on a regular basis of "your just a casual and I don't have to give you an answer". Stop telling casuals to work less because they make the regulars look bad. 

Not what I was expecting total and complete facade of what Harley Davidson ever was.

pros: All around great company to work for.  It is not a bother coming to work everyday, you actually enjoy it.  Has a very laid back overall feel.  You are given free time and can make your own schedule, but if there is a deadline you better hit it.  Pay is very good as is the benefits.  Relocation package was very helpful as well.
cons: Fast paced.  Management is constantly in meetings.  Can make learning all of the ins and outs of the company a little difficult.  Everyone is very nice and people who are not on your team will help as much as possible.

review_title: Management needs to Trust people  - not the same place it used to be
pros: Great Brand, fun co-workers, customers are amazingly passionate and loyal, strong benefits, fun events, cool products
cons: Executive team hasn't changed in many years, CYA common, trust is hard to find, little empowerment, all the inspirational leaders have left. Not taking on the sacred cows.

pros: Best American made motor cycle manufacturing company. Or at least it used to be. Good vacation, average insurance, holidays, discounts on bikes and clothes and accessories, iconic brand, advanced manufacturing facilities, decent cafeteria, flexible schedule.
cons: Long hours and lots of crisis management, poor relationships between union workers and salary workers (not all, but some) lower pay for salary workers, good old boy club still exists, favoritism in advancement, poor management decisions, bad managers left in charge, blame game put on lower level workers, saw innocent people get fired for made up reasons to protect managers.

review_title: James L Ziemer has annouced his retirement
pros: Riding the bikes is excellent if you get to test them.  Using the engineering tools is good, but they do not allow enough time to get it done right.  Cutting corners is the best way to meet the time lines and stay in good graces.  Then you have to blame others to protect yourself.  This is the best way to work at this company.
cons: The office politiics are over the top, really a hard place to create new products.  Because they do not really create new products, it is really impossible to innnovate and take the time to listen to teammates. The only way to blame others and lie, cheat and talk your way to the tap, which is really sad.

pros: You have exposure to the best customers anywhere on earth. Their passion for H-D can help sustain you when things are not good. Many great, ethical employees who really “get it.”  There are a precious few top leaders left who know the business, are collaborative, humble and constructive. The motorcycles are excellent and you can truly be proud of them. The product development people are top notch and get very little credit for the success of Harley. Read below…marketing gets credit for everything good that happens.
cons:
If I wanted to send H-D into decline, I’d start by a personnel environment where far too many people get “exceeds expectations” on their annual reviews. I’d make sure to move people from one job into another job they have no business doing. I wouldn’t move the incompetent out of H-D, I’d move them around. I’d pay my people too little while admonishing them “You get to work for Harley,” as if they could pay their mortgage with that. As a leader, I’d respond to any questions or pleas for help defensively. I’d play favorites openly…because what are you going to do about it? I’d promote my friend every 18 months and barely talk to the rest. I’d work year in and year out without a long term strategy. Jumping from harried tactic to harried tactic is easier on me, and it’s also kind of fun. It makes me feel creative.

I'd throw impossible expectations on people and end it with the "One Team, One Company!" mantra. After all, I don't have to do the work, you do. 

I’d push “project management” but not hold the leadership accountable when they waste a department’s time on their own subjective whims. I’d bring in a bunch of egomaniacs from General Motors (that bastion of excellence) and give them cart blanch. I’d reward leaders who waste millions of dollars and staff hours on poorly formed ideas and then pull the plug just before its done. I’d take dwindling or stagnant monetary resources and spread them across an ever-rising number of marketing programs and initiatives. More is always better. I’d worry only about shareholder value as quality issues multiply and customer satisfaction drops. I’d make sure ALL of the credit goes to narcissistic marketing leaders while everyone else is told to keep quiet. 

I’d rest on the laurels of what Harley was 20 years ago when it had no domestic competition.

I’d try to explain away how Polaris bought a dead brand and is beating Harley over the head with it.

But then, someone got a head start on me.

review_title: Decent benefits and a passion for motorcycles keeps me going
job_title: Marketing Project Manager in Milwaukee, WI
pros: It's an amazing brand recognized around the world - when you say you work for Harley, you'll feel proud . Good 401(k), profit sharing, great maternity/paternity benefits, casual dress... And of course... Motorcycles are awesome.
cons: The arrogant leadership in Marketing doesn't set clear goals which can cause drain on employee engagement. Highly political environment in the Marketing department. Questions around morals arise.

review_title: Harley davidson is a sinking ship!
pros: Employee for 19 years. It used to be a great company to work for. Nothing good to say about it anymore.
cons: The last 6 years the company has completely restructured for the worse.  The list of cons is huge. Here are just a few. They use and abuse the use of a casual work force.  Benefits are one of the worst tiers that they could provide. Management is unprofessional and micromanage just because they can. The good old boy system is very much alive at Harley Davidson and it's disgusting to watch. Mandated weeks of 12 hours a day 7 days a week is normal. Then huge layoffs, it's feast or famine which makes for a very unbalanced life. They have an attendance point system that is unrealistic which includes 0 sick days.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Allen, TX
pros: Great name, great legacy, People are friendly or so it seems.
cons: Very difficult to get anything done, lots of redundant jobs and people are in roles because they have intellectual capital that they refuse to share with anyone and management refuses to step up and challenge them.   PMO is immature and PMO management is very unrealistic on expectations and provides little to no training/support, yet expect full delivery and capability of all projects within all portfolios.

review_title: Great company that might be losing its way
pros: informal dress code, competitive pay, 3 weeks vacation to start and another week in 5 years,  and we design the best motorcycles in the world.
cons: Everything for the employee is being downgraded or taken away, one small perk at a time.  Quality of leadership varies in different areas of the company.  HR department is extremely corrupt. Many years of short-sighted decisions have taken tremendous toll on health of the company.  Many employees that have been here longer than 20 years have been leaving.  Industry is also lock step with the economy and motorcycle industry, so when there's a dip you can bet there'll be another round of layoffs.

review_title: If you're smart, you can do better
job_title: IT Project Manager in Milwaukee, WI
pros: The product, good people who work hard, discounts on bikes, rallys, pay is okay.
cons: Dwindling benefits, multiple layers of management (leadership) which equates to big bureaucracy.  Managers report to managers, Sr. Managers, Directors with one report, this company isn't big enough to support that kind of structure.  Too political; promotions seem to go to fast talkers, egotists, people who kiss up and back-stabbers.  Applying for opportunities in other areas just makes your current boss mad.

pros: Legendary motorcycles, dedicated employees, terrific and strong brand.   A reverse cult.  Customer base is terrific and you get the opportunity to engage directly with the end customers.  Dealers are very committed business people that run retailers that provide motorcycles, service, parts and accessories, and clothing to their customers - and they are very passionate about this.
cons: The company has a unique culture that needs to evolve, and soon!.  Leadership is not world class and their behavior has reputation among staffers as immature, unprofessional, lacking values and ethics. A sad commentary on this great company. It takes a long time for company to introduce advancements probably due to elongated decision making process, dependence on those who talk loudest, little innovation, and silos.  Poor performers and leaders seem to be rewarded.  If you are under 40, and a high performer, your career may be prioritized (for now).  Primarily a male dominated environment, with cultural bias in opportunities and pay — diversity and inclusion not prioritized.  Opportunities for advancement lacking - the same executives seem to be rotated around the company for the best opportunities and these are the ones best connected to the executive leadership team, but not necessarily the most talented employees or the best leaders.  Seems to have a preoccupation on overassessing their workforce through a series of talent management processes, testing, people days etc. - employees are highly and inappropriately "diagnosed" for professional capabilities by unqualified and ineffective leadership teams and this can have a long-lasting impact on the careers of their hard working and dedicated employees as their are few impactful employee development plans in progress where employees feel that they are being groomed for success.

review_title: Great Job, Great Co-Workers/Supervisors, rough time for the company
pros: I thuroughly enjoyed working at Harley-Davidson. It was a great learning experience. My co-workers were great and the feedback was always constructive.
cons: The company is very devout to its employees, or at least has been. So much so that it has many people who've overstayed their welcome and are causing the company to lose sight of the markets it should be engaging. The company will suffer for several years as a result and I'm sad to say my internship did not lead to full time employment. Nevertheless I do not regret taking the job for a second.

review_title: Was a great company till 2010 and since then it's been corkscrewing itself into the ground
job_title: Senior Project Engineer in Wauwatosa, WI
pros: The people here are great. The compensation & perks used to be great!
cons: Stress, Stress, Stress No promotions, No personal growth, work-life balance the life part of it no longer exists. Management still thinks this is the greatest place in the world to work at "WRONG" most people here don't trust management anymore and are actively looking to move on! still too much of the good ole boys club, if your in good with your dept. manager you got it made, the rest of us have to take up their slack!  lab leads & managers here are a joke!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, MO
pros:
Absolutely the BEST culture. Lot of long haired people and jeans, college students (co ops), etc and still a diverse culture. Great, fun, people. Great pay. Job is very fast paced and solutions for problems must be solved in minutes. No time for time wasters or new guys.

Changes made in engineering is fast, little resistance, quick changes to improvements.
cons:
Meetings are super slow, very disorganized. Don't seem be very serious although it is effective to make changes to improvements.

Professional staff dresses down, t shirts and jeans. It should be at least casual. Many tours at the facility and customers see this and may interpret it as not running things seriously.

review_title: Love It Here! Culture Needs Some Improvement...
pros: Great team environment.  The culture and people are energetic.  We get to work around the culture and lifestyle of motorcycles, with some of the most dedicated customers in the world.  The history in the company is more than any book or TV series could ever communicate.

pros: If you like to work on CAD drawings all day with unrealistic deadlines and dealing with management direction change on a daily basis then this is the place for you.

The engineering work environment at the PDC is high stress and the amount of people churn is unbelievable.  It is rare that a project will finish with at least 25% of the the original team members that started on it.  Forget about performance reviews as it is not uncommon to be shuffled around like a deck of cards and work under different manager over the course of a year that have no clue of your skill set, experiences or prior achievements.   

Management has no clear direction except time lines and it is not uncommon to get an email at 2:00pm requesting a new task to be completed before COB without regards to your other work commitments.  If you don't deliver you will get "you did not meet my expectations and are not planning for success".  Managers will talk out of both sides of their mouth and never make commitments, while having perfect 20/20 hind sight on why missed deadlines are due to your lack of commitment.  Going above and beyond to resolve issues is rarely recognized and will usually come back to bite you.  CYA is the name of the game there so if you do take a job make sure you save every email.  Ask for help on a project and the typical response is "get me your action plan for how you are going to resolve this".  

There are just too many layers of managers leading to a high level of dysfunction.  Excessive paperwork and documentation on their design methodology prevents any time for true innovation or design work  be completed.  Managers are concerned with "checking the box" for documentation rather than the true design being correct and reliable, but they will preach otherwise when the situation calls for it.

If you interview most likely the people you talk to were selected randomly and will not be your direct co-workers as you will be assigned a different role once you walk in the door.  It is not uncommon for them to shuffle around EEs to do ME work and MEs doing electrical products - reflects managements lack of interest in developing talent and more interested in developing "engineering robots" that can be tossed around to fight one fire to the next.

Excessive meetings are used and scheduled to discuss every little detail which leaves little or no time for actual work to take place.  Not uncommon to be double or tipple booked for meetings during any given hour of the day.  If you get into a crunch expect daily or even hourly status update meetings with managers who add no value to the task at hand and only want to know when the issue will be resolved and why you are behind schedule - well maybe if you quit the hourly meetings we could get some work done and resolve the issue.

Leadership communication with employees is very impersonal, one-directional, insincere, and condescending.  Outsourcing of all functions, including some core engineering development, is becoming more prevalent, even where quality of outsourced work is substantially lower, while being very expensive.  Technical experts are randomly appointed, often with very little or no experience in the area of expertise, while the actual experts are equally randomly misplaced in roles that require completely different skills and experiences. 

Human resource department provides only hiring and firing services, and provide virtually no value to employees.  Career path and employee development is routinely reserved only for the few preselected employees, and it is not part of the company culture and operating principles.  Work/life balance is severely impacted by high internal turnover, frequent rework caused by poor decisions, and highly stressful work environment.  Individuality and creativity are being increasingly supressed by implementation of standardized processes and methodologies, regardless of how flawed and inefficient these processes actually are. 

While most agree that a major re-organization of HD Engineering was overdue, it was planned very poorly, and executed even worse.  Consequently, the new organization is very unstable and likely unsustainable.  

As a result of years of poor engineering leadership, Harley-Davidson has become a terrible place for engineers who want to perform at the highest levels.  Instead, it has become an environment that fosters mediocrity and obedience at the expense of passion and ingenuity.
